title: You Probably Can’t Use the Yield Curve to Time the...
text:
The article agrees with recession following inverted yields but challenges poor stock performance following yield curve inversion. He does refer to a study on this but for some reason isn't providing any real data or chart as he does for recessions. I believe more often than not, stocks have fallen significantly at some point after inversion, enough so to count on. In the current environment, I think money is likely to move out of stocks for reasons that would not be as motivating in times past, due to investors being skittish about a host of other things, some of which have no direct effect on the market, such as the fact that this bull market is 10 years old.

And, using treasuries as a benchmark for stock performance seems like a low bar. Wouldn't stocks earning slightly above treasuries would be a decline from normal?
